answers.answer: If I were in your shoes I would get a second opinion from ANOTHER doctor - run don't walk. I saw several PCP's before I found one that I liked, one that listens to me, guides me in the right direction, and, best of all, takes care of me the way I feel a doctor should.I would get another fasting glucose test and don't cheat. Do NOT eat or consume anything but water for a minimum of 8 hours prior to the test. And, I would also get a Hemoglobin A1c (HgBA1c) test. This  will determine whether you are a diabetic candidate or a diabetic.

Thank you for the advice, I appreciate it.  The last test was definitely on nothing but water for maybe 10 hours, so I am confident it was accurate.  Could I really go from 110 to diabetic in three months?  Doesn't seem possible from what I have read?

Yes. I don't what or where you read your information but what you stuffed into your mouth and swallowed during those three months played a huge role in pushing your glucose level upwards. A 110 fasting, by most doctors, is considered pre-diabetic in the USA. Anything over 120, unless you're on immunosuppressant medication, is considered diabetic in the USA.Good luck.This is the Web site to read, follow, and learn how to control diabetes http://www.ndep.nih.gov/diabetes/control/principles.htmKeep in mind, "Diet and daily physical activity help to control type 2 diabetes."

Oh yeah... get another doc."Dot.Calm" gave great advice.First and foremost, no medical professional should ever be dismissive, but sadly, there are many who are. The ultimate truth is that you (and this is true for all of us) have to be the ultimate advocate for your own health.  Your posting here suggests that you already on your way to doing that for yourself.  Good for you!  Find a doc you can communicate with and who, at the least, you feel is not dismissive.  After all, it IS your health and your body and please remember that.Also... yes, you can "develop" diabetes that fast, at least in terms of lab tests 'catching up' to what is going on in your body.  So, please, search for a doc you can trust, but until you find one, keep seeing *some* medical professional to monitor your health, as you are clearly feeling that your body is not ok.You did not mention what kind of "strict diet" you are on.  Some extreme/strict diets can actually be very bad for diabetic health.  Seeing a nutritionist might be helpful, too...Let us know what you do and what happens...

I cut out all sweets and refined carbohydrates and have been eating basically fish, chicken, tofu, salads, nuts, seeds, fruits (but not juice), vegetables, a little cheese here and there, a little brown rice here and there.  Hard for me to believe my blood sugar could have really zoomed up on that diet particularly to the point where thirst symptoms develop which I understand is not at the beginning stages of type II but only after glucose is regularly past the renal threshold.  Anyhow I will push my doctor for some answers.
Oh I should add i have been taking some of the supplements I see recommended for lowering blood sugar as well including chromium picolinate, magnesium, biotin and cinammon.

Sounds like you're on the right track overall, but finding a doc you can communicate with is more important, and I still suggest seeing a nutritionist for at least a consultation and to review what and how much you're consuming.OH!  I meant to comment on this before:  the blood glucose meter...  getting readings between 111-118 over a 5 minute period isn't necessarily a sign that the meter is off.  Most meters need to be calibrated, and you should use 'test solution' to make sure the meter *is* working properly.  Also, it's not unheard of for anxiety or frustration (with the meter itself, for example) to actually cause a small rise in blood glucose.  Plus, sometimes if I'm sleepy or distracted I still get "off" readings because the test strip didn't fill enough.   Regardless... a meter is still the best way for you to personally monitor your blood glucose and see what effect different foods have... no meter is perfect, so it's the trends over time that matter more than any individual reading.Good luck, and let us know how things go...

Thrist was one of my first indications I had diabetes, along with sores that didn't heal for months. I don't have renal problems (so far), but I definately have tye 2 diabetes. I can't eat fruits and cheese without my blood sugar going up. A nutritianist is a good place to start. And I agree, find a doc you are comfortable with. Good luck.

question: Any advice appreciated.  For a number of months I have had frequent thirst, at times quite pronounced, and a very high urine output first thing in the AM (occasionally during the night too) as well as a couple of hours after waking.However, when my fasting blood sugar was checked in May of this year, when I first had these symptoms, it was "only" 110.  My PCP said to lose some weight but it could not possibly be diabetes.  Last month, when they got even worse, I did buy a meter and  got readings ranging from 111-118 within the space of five minutes.  I decided that  the thing was useless and chucked it.Based on my reading I assume I could not have progressed THAT quickly into diabetes (110 seems a long way from 126), and also based on my reading it sounds like you don't really get the thirst/urination thing until well after the initial threshold anyhow.  My PCP has assured me I couldn't possibly have diabetes and won't even re-test me, she says I am being hypochondriacal.I have been on a strict diet for at least a month, but the problem really hasn't changed, which I guess also points against having type II?  Or is that too soon to make a difference?BUT, the bottom line is I can't seem to find any other explanation and I can't even talk to my doctor about it as she is completely dismissive.Sorry to ramble, any thoughts or advice appreciated.
title: Confused whether I could have type II
